awd_titl_txt: Targeted Infusion Project: Enhancing the Undergraduate Computing Curriculum by Infusing Cybersecurity and Digital Forensics Concepts
awd_abstract_narration:
The Historically Black Colleges and Universities Undergraduate Program (HBCU-UP) through Targeted Infusion Projects supports the development, implementation, and study of evidence-based innovative models and approaches for improving the preparation and success of HBCU undergraduate students so that they may pursue science, technology, engineering or mathematics (STEM) graduate programs and/or careers. The project at Alabama State University seeks to enhance the computing curriculum by integrating cybersecurity and digital forensics concepts. Undergraduate students are involved in the project as researchers.

This project has the objectives to: adapt methods for cybersecurity training in computing courses and integrate cybersecurity concepts in existing courses; create a new course on digital forensics; develop and test instructional materials; design and develop a cyber range; use war-gaming to teach cybersecurity concepts; collect and analyze achievement of outcome based on student and industry feedback; support faculty development in cybersecurity; and guide students to obtain cybersecurity certification. This project will enhance understanding of how cybersecurity and digital forensics concepts can be integrated within a classroom environment and translate into a framework of pedagogy and materials relevant and enabling for teaching computer science. The project will directly benefit about 300 students and is designed to improve the quality of STEM education, thus increasing the minority STEM talent pool of rigorously prepared students for the workforce, graduate or professional school. The project will be guided by an external evaluator, as well as internal and external advisory committees.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Background: Cyberattacks, including identity theft and life-threatening threats, pose a growing threat to our nation. To employ sufficiently qualified security personnel, the industry confronts significant challenges. The well-documented shortage of STEM graduates who are qualified to work in the cyber field is one of the obstacles in addressing cyber workforce issues. Our undergraduate computing courses do not provide students with the necessary training in cybersecurity areas that integrate theory and practice. By teaching these skills to students, their employability is significantly increased. 

Objectives: The proposed initiative aims to adapt methods for cybersecurity training in computing courses; integrate cybersecurity concepts into existing courses; develop a new digital forensics course; create and assess instructional content; design and construct a cyber range; utilizing wargames to teach cybersecurity concepts; collecting and analyzing student feedback; and motivate and direct students to obtain cybersecurity certification.

Major Activities: We developed, taught, and assessed a digital forensics course and cybersecurity-infused modules in five core computing courses that immerse students in active learning of real-world cybersecurity practices. At each stage of the project lifecycle, our course guided students through the process of developing a functional solution by requiring them to utilize cybersecurity modules designed to implement cutting-edge industry techniques. Each week, a lifecycle activity was introduced to the curriculum to teach the stages of the process. Students worked in an interactive environment where they were instructed on new techniques and then guided through a series of practical exercises in the application of these techniques.

Intellectual Merit: This project enhanced our understanding of how to implement cybersecurity concepts in the classroom. The findings resulted in a relevant and valuable pedagogical framework and instructional materials for teaching cybersecurity. Several previously unaddressed research issues were investigated. These include the need to include cybersecurity concepts in computing courses; the need for cyber range in teaching cybersecurity; the need for support materials that can be used with a variety of textbooks; the impact of courses that include cybersecurity concepts on student learning and employment; and the impact of engaging students in wargaming teams to solve real cybersecurity problems.

Broader Impact: This initiative had a significant impact on how undergraduate information assurance courses are taught and how students acquire these concepts. The development of learning materials and instructional strategies was guided by the participation of faculty from diverse institutions and industry practitioners. This initiative significantly increased the capacity of Alabama State University, a HBCU, to conduct nationally recognized research in cybersecurity education. We disseminated our findings through various channels, including publications in journals and at conferences, student symposium presentations, and Outreach seminars. Additionally, over 150 students received direct benefits from this initiative over the course of its five-year duration; more than 90% of these students are underrepresented minorities and female students.

Major Outcomes

1. New course and course modules: We have developed a new digital forensics course and five new cybersecurity-infused course curricula, lecture materials, and lab experiments. These modules are likely to have an impact on how undergraduate courses are taught in US universities.

2.Student knowledge and confidence: Students experienced real-world cybersecurity practices through active learning using the modules and associated tools developed in this project. The student feedback and survey results indicate that the sequence of topics would allow students to experience the benefit of working in a disciplined fashion. Our study shows students were highly confident in their cybersecurity engagement and Self-Efficacy, Engineering Self-Efficacy, Academic Efficacy, 21st Century Skills, Career Readiness, Persistence, problem-solving skills, ability to develop working solutions to defend cyberspace and computer networks, and their understanding of critical concepts and industry skills.

3.URM training: We provided yearlong professional training to 18 URM students in computer networking and cybersecurity from industrial specialists. Through this effort, over 150 URM STEM majors received cybersecurity training.

4.Community workshops: We held four workshops on cybersecurity for students and the educational community, fifteen free bootcamps for high school students, and a cybersecurity bootcamp for youth.

5.Undergraduate students' research: We developed an undergraduate URM research group in cybersecurity through this initiative, and 11 students successfully completed yearlong research projects and presented their findings at peer-reviewed conferences.

6.Faculty Development: This project provided cybersecurity and digital forensics training to two faculty members.

7.STEM interdisciplinary research initiative: Our STEM interdisciplinary faculty team spent the summer of 2020 devising and testing active learning modules and research projects on the intersection of cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and big data.

8.Cybersecurity lab: This initiative has provided funding for the establishment of a cybersecurity lab.

9.Students peer-teaching opportunity and retention: Thanks to this initiative, we were able to place exceptional seniors as peer tutors in a student-run support lab. These student employees aided the unit's retention efforts by tutoring students in STEM subjects and assisting with their cybersecurity assignments/projects.

10.Publications: With the support of this project, 11 peer-reviewed papers were published.


Last Modified: 07/31/2023
Modified by: Uma Kannan
